content:
Fixed the extra space in test 3:

&(-12, -6) -> &(-12,-6)

It was the only time it happened and it seemed to be unintended by the likes of the statement, but maybe I'm wrong. If so, feel free to add it back.

âœ… Approved the contribution.
Comment: Nice easy puzzle. The statement is clear and the topic should be well known to most people. The trickiest part for me was the parsing and I wished the input was giving in a more friendly format, but I guess it was good practice too.

âœ… Approved the contribution.
Comment: Good puzzle

âœ… Approved the contribution.
Comment: Nice easy puzzle !

Hey CodinGamer! Your contribution has unfortunately not been moderated on time and will temporarily be removed from the system... But no worries! You can republish it anytime to give it another chance! :)

Is it guaranteed that vector names will be unique across points? If so, you may consider mentioning that too within statement or constraints.

Also, around Input and Output, 
rather than showing Output Line 1 formatted for A and B vector as "AB(xb-xa,yb-xa,zb-za)", a generalised one shall fit in better such as "AB(b1-a1, b2-a2, ..., bn-an)" which matches as it is mentioned in goal statement too.
Similarly for 'N next lines' part of the Input section, "A(0, 1, 2)" can be replaced with "A(1, 2, ..., D)" which shows that the vector will have points as per a given dimension as 'D'

Seems like a fun puzzle overall

âœ… Approved the contribution.
Comment: This puzzle is easy but requires the use of notions such as the manipulation of  strings, array sorting  or even number formatting. OK for me ;-)

Hi,
The goal states the shortest (non zero) but there's no need to check for 0 as it never happens, maybe you could add a test/validator with at least 2 two points sharing the same coordinates.

âœ… Approved the contribution.
Comment: Nice puzzle, pretty simple, deserve to be accepted as puzzle

Goal section
* Please fix the typos:
   â€¢ "exercice" => "exercise"
   â€¢ "greaters" => "higher"
   â€¢ "bigger" => do you mean "longest"?

Input/Output section
* Please fix the typos:
   â€¢ "dimension" => "dimensions"
   â€¢ "appear" => "appears"
   â€¢ "bigger" => do you mean "longest"?

Constraints section
* Is it guaranteed that the shortest vector and the longest vector in each case are both unique (e.g. there won't be two shortest vectors of the same length)? Please state so if that is the case.

Thanks.
Would you consider uploading a cover picture for the puzzle?

I don't think that is necessary, I specified non-zero because if you look rigorously, AA is a vector, from A to A so it is null for every component. By that I meant to output the shortest vector between different points.

Well I can mention that but every point has a different name with the same number of letters. The only exception is Test 3 but you'll easily see you can't have two vectors with the same name.
As for AB(b1-a1, ...,bn-an), I don't realy know why I did it that way, thanks for noticing and thanks for your comment I'm going to correct all that.

Thanks for the consideration and quick fix

If I may add, 
- please also look into "As in 2D:" mentioned incompletely in goal statement 
- In the first para that mentioned "... to output the shortest (non-zero) and the longest vectors you can form from your list", it would be good to add something like- by pairing or using any two points in combination

Smaller finishing clarities added now shall keep the problem as well set when published ðŸ˜€
I don't see what problem there is for the "As in 2D" but good second point, it's done.
